Let F (s) = 1 (2s − 1)(2s − 3) . Find f (t) = L−1[F (s)]. Answer. We ﬁrst rewrite: F (s) = 1 (2s−1)(2s−3) = 1 4 · 1 (s− 1 2 )(s− 3 2 ) . We then use partial fractions to write: 1 (s− 1 2 )(s− 3 2 ) = 1 s− 3 2 − 1 s− 1 2 . Using the ﬁrst shifting property (s-shift) and L−1[ 1 s ](t) = C, we obtain: f (t) = L −1[F (s)](t) = 1 4 [ e 3 2 t − e t 2 ] . 2. Let F (s) = 3s (s + 1)4 . Find f (t) = L−1[F (s)]. Answer. Notice that: F (s) = 3s (s+1)4 = 3(s+1−1) (s+1)4 = 3(s+1)−3 (s+1)4 = 3 (s+1)3 − 3 (s+1)4 . Using the ﬁrst shifting property and L−1[ n! sn+1 ](t) = tn, we obtain: f (t) = L −1[F (s)](t) = 3L −1 [ 1 (s + 1)3 ] − 3L −1 [ 1 (s + 1)4 ] = 3e −t [ t2 2 − t3 6 ] . 3. Let F (s) = 1 s(s + 1)2 . Find f (t) = L−1[F (s)] using the following two diﬀerent methods: (a) Partial fractions, (b) Laplace transform of integrals. Answer. (a) Partial fractions: We ﬁrst rewrite: F (s) = 1 s(s+1)2 = 1 s − 1 s+1 − 1 (s+1) 2 . Using the ﬁrst shifting property and L−1[ n! sn+1 ](t) = tn, we obtain: f (t) = L −1[F (s)](t) = 1 − e −t − te−t = 1 − e −t [1 + t] (b) Laplace transform of integrals: We know that : L−1[ 1 s F (s)](t) = ∫ t 0 f (τ )dτ . Therefore: L−1[F (s)](t) = ∫ t 0 L−1 [ 1 (s+1)2 ] (τ ) dτ = ∫ t 0 e−τ τ dτ. Using integration by parts, we obtain: f (t) = L −1[F (s)](t) = 1 − e −t [1 + t] Note here that the integral method is identical to using the Laplace transform of a convolution. 4. Let F (s) = 1 s (s2 + 2s + 3) . Find f (t) = L−1[F (s)] using the formula for the Laplace trans- form of an integral. Hint: Use integration by parts two times to write an equation for the unknown I = ∫ t 0 e−t sin( √2t). 2 Answer. Notice that: 1 s2+2s+3 = 1 (s+1)2+2 . Using the Laplace transform of integrals, the ﬁrst shifting property and L−1[ ω s2+ω2 ](t) = sin(ωt), we obtain: L−1[F (s)](t) = 1√2 ∫ t 0 e−τ sin(√2τ )dτ . We then introduce the variable: I = ∫ t 0 e−τ sin(√2τ )dτ , and integrate by parts twice: I = ∫ t 0 e −τ sin( √2τ )dτ = [−e −τ sin( √2τ )]t 0 + √2 ∫ t 0 e −τ cos(√2τ )dτ = −e−t sin( √2t) + √2 [−e −τ cos(√2τ )]t 0 − 2 ∫ t 0 e −τ sin(√2τ )dτ = −e−t sin( √2t) − √2e−t cos(√2t) + √ 2 − 2I. Therefore, we obtain f (t) = L −1[F (s)](t) = 1 3 − 1 3 e −t cos(√2t) − 1 3 √2 e−t sin( √2t) Note that the question can also be solved using partial fractions. 5. Solve using the Laplace transform the initial-value problem: y′′+y = t, y(0) = 2 and y′(0) = 2. Answer. Let Y (s) = L[y(t)](s). We apply the Laplace transform on both sides of the ODE and obtain: s2Y − y′(0) − sy(0) + Y = 1 s2 . Using the initial conditions, we obtain: (s 2 + 1)Y = 1 s2 + 2s + 2. We then obtain: Y = 1 s2+1 [ 1 s2 + 2s + 2] = 1 s2(s2+1) + 2s s2+1 + 2 s2+1 . Noticing that: 1 s2(s2+1) = 1 s2 − 1 s2+1 , we have: Y = 1 s2 − 1 s2 + 1 + 2s s2 + 1 + 2 s2 + 1 = 1 s2 + 2s s2 + 1 + 1 s2 + 1 . We ﬁnally obtain: y(t) = L −1[Y (s)](t) = L −1 [ 1 s2 ] + 2L−1 [ s s2 + 1 ] + L −1 [ 1 s2 + 1 ] = t + 2 cos(t) + sin(t). 6. Solve using the Laplace transform the initial-value problem: x′′ + 4x′ + 5x = 1 and x(0) = x′(0) = 0. 3 Answer. Let X(s) = L[x(t)](s). We apply the Laplace transform on both sides of the ODE and obtain: s2X − x′(0) − sx(0) + 4sX − 4x(0) + 5X = 1 s . Using the initial conditions, we obtain: (s2 + 4s + 5)X = 1 s . We then obtain X(s) = 1 s(s2+4s+5) = 1 s((s+2)2+1) . Noticing that: 1 s(s2+4s+5) = A s + Bs+C s2+4s+5 , with A = 1 5 , B = − 1 5 , C = − 4 5 , we obtain: X(s) = 1 s(s2 + 4s + 5) = 1 5 · 1 s − 1 5 · s + 4 s2 + 4s + 5 = 1 5 · 1 s − 1 5 · s + 2 + 2 (s + 2)2 + 1 = 1 5 · 1 s − 1 5 · s + 2 (s + 2)2 + 1 − 2 5 · 1 (s + 2)2 + 1 . Using the ﬁrst shifting property, we have: x(t) = L−1[X(s)](t) = 1 5 L −1 [ 1 s ] − 1 5 L −1 [ s + 2 (s + 2)2 + 1 ] − 2 5 L −1 [ 1 (s + 2)2 + 1 ] = 1 5 − e−2t 5 L −1 [ s s2 + 1 ] − 2e−2t 5 L −1 [ 1 s2 + 1 ] = 1 5 − 1 5 e −2t cos(t) − 2 5 e −2t sin(t). 7. Find L[f (t)], where: f (t) =    1, if 0 ≤ t < 1, t2, if 1 ≤ t < 2, 4, if t ≥ 2. Answer. We ﬁrst rewrite f (t) using Heaviside functions: f (t) = 1 · [u(t − 0) − u(t − 1)] + t2[u(t − 1) − u(t − 2)] + 4[u(t − 2) − u(t − ∞)] = 1 − u(t − 1) + t 2u(t − 1) − t 2u(t − 2) + 4u(t − 2) = 1 + (t 2 − 1)u(t − 1) − (t 2 − 4)u(t − 2). Using the second shifting property, we have: L[f (t)](s) = L[1] + L[(t 2 − 1)u(t − 1)] − L[(t 2 − 4)u(t − 2)] = 1 s + e−sL[(t + 1)2 − 1] − e −2sL[(t + 2)2 − 4] = 1 s + e−sL[t 2 + 2t] − e −2sL[t2 + 4t] = 1 s + e−s [ 2 s3 + 2 s2 ] − e−2s [ 2 s3 + 4 s2 ] . 4 8. Find the Laplace transform of the solution to the initial-value problem: x′′ + 2x′ + x = f (t) and x(0) = x′(0) = 0, with: f (t) = { 2, if 0 ≤ t ≤ 2, t, if t > 2. Answer. Let X(s) = L[x(t)]. We apply the Laplace transform on both sides of the ODE and obtain: (s 2 + 2s + 1)X = L[f (t)](s). We then rewrite f (t) using Heaviside function: f (t) = 2[u(t − 0) − u(t − 2)] + t[u(t − 2) − u(t − ∞)] = 2[1 − u(t − 2)] + tu(t − 2) = 2 + (t − 2)u(t − 2). Therefore we have using the second shifting property: L[f (t)](s) = 2L[1] + L[(t − 2)u(t − 2)] = 2 s + e−2sL[t](s) = 2 s + e−2s s2 . We ﬁnally obtain: L[x(t)](s) = X(s) = 1 (s + 1)2 [ 2 s + e−2s s2 ] . 9. Let F (s) = s (s2 + 1)2 . Find f (t) = L−1[F (s)] using the Laplace transform of a convolution. Hint: cos(a) sin(b) = 1 2 [sin(a + b) − sin(a − b)] and cos(−t) = cos(t). Answer. Using the Laplace transform of a convolution, we obtain: L −1 [ s (s2 + 1)2 ] = L−1 [ 1 s2 + 1 ] ∗ L−1 [ s s2 + 1 ] = ∫ t 0 sin(τ ) cos(t − τ ) dτ = 1 2 ∫ t 0 [sin(t) − sin(t − 2τ )] dτ = 1 2 [ sin(t)τ − 1 2 cos(t − 2τ ) ]t 0 = 1 2 [t sin(t) − 1 2 cos(t) + 1 2 cos(−t) ] = 1 2 t sin(t). 5 10. Let F (s) = s (s + 1)(s2 + 1) . Find f (t) = L−1[F (s)] using the Laplace transform of a convo- lution. Hint: Use integration by parts two times to write an equation for the unknown I = ∫ t 0 e−t cos(τ − t)dτ . Answer. Using the Laplace transform of a convolution and the ﬁrst shifting property, we obtain: L −1[F (s)](t) = L −1 [ s (s + 1)(s2 + 1) ] = L −1 [ 1 (s + 1) ] ∗ L−1 [ s s2 + 1 ] = ∫ t 0 e−τ cos(t − τ ) dτ = ∫ t 0 e−τ cos(τ − t) dτ. We now introduce the variable: I = ∫ t 0 e−τ cos(τ − t)dτ , and integrate by parts twice: I = ∫ t 0 e−τ cos(τ − t)dτ = [ −e −τ cos(τ − t) ]t 0 − ∫ t 0 e−τ sin(τ − t)dτ = −e−t + cos(t) − [−e −τ sin(τ − t)]t 0 − ∫ t 0 e−τ cos(τ − t)dτ = −e−t + cos(t) + sin(t) − I. Finally we obtain: f (t) = L −1[F (s)](t) = 1 2 [sin(t) + cos(t) − e−t]. 6
